questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain, confusion, and difficulty walking. Examination reveals moderate pallor, blue-black lines on his gums (shown in the image below), and bilateral foot drop. Which heavy metal poisoning is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Heavy metal

Source of exposure

Clinical features

Lead

(Option C)

Non-industrial

  • Gasoline from automobile exhaust.
  • Contaminated water from lead pipes.
  • Lead paints in old homes.
 

Industrial

  • Battery and cosmetic manufacturing
  • Printing paint and dye factories
  • Glass manufacturing
  • Shipbuilding

Organic lead

  • Wrist and/or foot drop.
  • Insomnia.
  • Headache.
  • Mental confusion.
 

Inorganic lead

  • Anemia.
  • Burton’s line - blue lines on gums.
  • Colic, abdominal pain with diarrhea/constipation.

 

Arsenic

(Option A)
  • Pesticide
  • Contaminated water
  • Copper and lead smelting
  • Wood preservatives

 

Acute poisoning

  • Gastroenteritis (Rice watery diarrhea) (differential diagnosis- cholera)
  • Hypotension
  • Non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema
  • Proteinuria
  • Seizures, delirium and encephalopathy
 

Subacute poisoning (1-3 weeks)

  • Glove stocking pattern polyneuropathy
  • Absent deep tendon reflex
  • Anemia, Leukopenia
 

Chronic poisoning

  • Raindrop pattern hyperpigmentation
  • Palmar-plantar hyperkeratosis
  • Alopecia
  • Angiosarcoma
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Gangrene of extremities.

Mercury

(Option B)
  • Fish (from water pollution)
  • Dental amalgam
  • Gold and mercury mining
  • Contaminated food and grains
  • Greying of the oral mucosa
  • Hemorrhagic gastroenteritis
  • Acute tubular necrosis
  • Shock
  • Excessive irritability
  • Acrodynia (painful extremities)
  • Facial paresthesias
  • Ataxia (loss of coordination), Dementia
  • Blindness

Cadmium

(Option D)
  • Smoking
  • Paint manufacturing
  • Nickel-cadmium battery manufacturing
  • Plastic production

 

Acute poisoning

  • Inhalation: Pneumonitis; ARDS
  • Ingestion: GIT hemorrhagic necrosis

Chronic poisoning

  • Osteomalacia
  • Parkinson like symptoms
  • Proteinuria

Raindrop pigmentation (Arsenic poisoning)

Acrodynia (Mercury poisoning)

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the objective of ergonomics?

options.label: A
options.text: Achieving optimal human performance and well-being through work adjustments.

options.label: B
options.text: Enhancing job satisfaction by adjusting tasks to fit human capabilities.

options.label: C
options.text: Ensuring workers perform efficiently without health risks.

options.label: D
options.text: Assessing job tasks to prevent health hazards.

questions.correct_answer: A. Achieving optimal human performance and well-being through work adjustments.

questions.text: Where is the National Institute of Occupational Health(Apex) of India located?
How frequently are periodic medical examinations typically conducted for employees in dichromate industries?
questions.explanation:
Periodicity

Examples

Annual (Once a year)
  • General industries
  • Office environments

Biannual (Once in six months)
  • Asbestos handling
  • Pharmaceutical production

Quarterly
  • Construction
  • Mining

Monthly
  • Chemical manufacturing
  • Heavy metal industries(Lead)
  • Radium and Ionsing radiation
  • Dye industries

Daily
  • Dichromate

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary objective of a pre-placement medical examination?

options.label: A
options.text: To evaluate the effectiveness of the company's health and safety programs.

options.label: B
options.text: To ensure the employee's ongoing health and fitness after being hired.

options.label: C
options.text: To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job they are being considered for.

options.label: D
options.text: To provide health benefits and insurance options to the new employee.

questions.correct_answer: C. To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job they are being considered for.
questions.explanation:
Criteria

Pre-Placement Examination

Post-Placement Examination

Timing

Before hiring/starting the job.

After the employee has started the job.

Purpose

To determine if the candidate is medically fit for the job.

To monitor the ongoing health and safety of employees.

Focus

Assess fitness for specific job tasks.

Detect work-related health issues and ensure continued fitness.

Outcome

Decision on hiring based on medical fitness

Implement interventions if health issues are detected.

Frequency

Once, before the job offer.

Periodically or as required during employment.

Legal Requirement

Often mandated by regulations for certain jobs

It may be required by occupational health and safety regulations

Examples of Usage

High-risk jobs (e.g., heavy machinery operators, pilots)

Jobs with ongoing exposure to hazards (e.g., chemical exposure)

questions.text: What does the sickness absenteeism rate measure?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of employees absent from work due to sickness.

options.label: B
options.text: The percentage of working hours lost due to employee absences caused by illness..

options.label: C
options.text: The average duration of sickness absences per employee per month.

options.label: D
options.text: The economic impact of sickness absences on the organisation

questions.correct_answer: B. The percentage of working hours lost due to employee absences caused by illness..

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with intermittent episodes of pale and white fingers followed by a dusky red colour, leading to a diagnosis of Raynaud's phenomenon. Considering his symptoms, what is his most likely occupation?
A 65-year-old male comes to the OPD due to hematuria. Cystoscopy reveals bladder cancer. Past occupational exposure to which of the following chemicals is associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoma

Occupation exposure

Lungs

Arsenic (Option D), beryllium, cadmium, Chromium, Asbestosis, Silica, radon, Nickel and aromatic hydrocarbon.

Bladder

Benzidine (Option B), Auramine, Beta-naphthylamine, Para amino-diphenyl, Magenta.

Liver

Vinyl chloride (Option A), Arsenic.

Leukaemia

Benzene (Option C), ethylene oxide.

Skin

Arsenic (Option D), ionising radiation, Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Scrotum

Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons.

Carcinoma

Occupation exposure

Bladder

Benzidine

Leukaemia

Benzene

questions.text: Which metal oxide fumes are most commonly implicated in causing metal fume fever?
Which of the following tests is the most sensitive test for screening for lead exposure?
questions.explanation:
Test

Inference

Urine coproporphyrin level (Option A)

Used as a screening test (>150 mcg is indicative of lead exposure)

Urine aminolevulinate (ALA) level (Option B)
  • Most sensitive and specific for screening.
  • Normal urine ALA: 1 to 6 mg/24 hours; in lead poisoning: >70 mg/24 hours.

Urine lead level

Quantitative indicator of lead exposure and absorption.

(Normal: 0.2 to 0.8 mg/L)

Blood lead level

(Option C)
  • Confirmatory test
  • Normal: < 10 mcg/dl
  • Occupational exposure: 40 mcg/dl
  • Treatment should be started if levels >70 mcg/dl

Peripheral blood smear

(Option D)

Examining basophilic stippling is a sensitive parameter for hematological response to lead levels and treatment of lead poisoning.

questions.text: A 45-year-old radiology technician consults his occupational health physician about his annual radiation exposure, concerned about potential health risks and whether his exposure is within safe limits. What is the maximum annual radiation exposure level a person can tolerate without significant health risks?

A 4-year-old child presents with irritability, loss of appetite, and developmental delays. The parents mention living in an old house undergoing renovation, with peeling paint and dust. Blood tests confirm elevated lead levels. What is the most common route of lead poisoning in this child?

A 38-year-old male factory worker at a sugarcane processing plant presents with a dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. On examination, bilateral inspiratory crackles are noted. Chest X-ray shows diffuse infiltrates, and spirometry indicates a restrictive pattern. What respiratory condition is he likely suffering from?

A 55-year-old male with over 30 years in the construction industry presents to the clinic with a chronic cough and shortness of breath. His history includes long-term asbestos exposure. Chest X-ray reveals interstitial fibrosis. The patient is concerned about complications from his occupational exposure. What is the most common manifestation in a patient with asbestosis?

A 60-year-old man presents with chronic cough, weight loss, and night sweats. He has worked in the mining industry for over 25 years. On examination, there are crackles in the upper lung fields, and a chest X-ray shows nodular opacities in the upper lobes. Which type of pneumoconiosis is most commonly associated with an increased risk of tuberculosis (TB)?

A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic with progressive shortness of breath and a chronic dry cough. He mentions working in shipbuilding for over 30 years. On examination, his lungs have a dull percussion note and fine crackles at the bases. A chest X-ray is performed. Which of the following is the characteristic radiologic change seen in this patient?
questions.explanation:
X-Ray Changes

Types of pneumoconiosis

Ground glass opacity

Asbestosis

Black lung

Anthracosis

Mottling of lung

Bagassosis (Option A)

Fine nodular opacity

Farmer's lung (Option C)

Snowstorm

Silicosis (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following factors plays a crucial role in determining the severity of pneumoconiosis in individuals exposed to mineral dust? 1) Fineness of particles 2) Chemical composition 3) Concentration of dust in the air 4) Period of exposure
questions.explanation:
Factor

Description

Chemical Composition

Different dust types have varying toxicity levels; silica and asbestos are particularly harmful.

Fineness of Particles

Finer particles can penetrate deeper into the lungs, causing more severe damage over time.

Concentration of Dust in the Air

Higher concentrations increase the likelihood and severity of respiratory issues upon inhalation.

Period of Exposure

Longer exposure durations, especially at high concentrations, increase cumulative lung damage.

Health Status of the Person Exposed

Pre-existing lung diseases like Asthma, COPD, smokers and immune status affect susceptibility.

questions.text: Match the following pneumoconiosis conditions with their related industries: Pneumoconiosis Exposure Industry 1. Silicosis a. Textile Manufacturing 2. Asbestosis b. Mining and Quarrying 3. Byssinosis c. Construction and Shipbuilding 4. Anthracosis d. Coal Mining

A 55-year-old coal miner with a history of fine dust exposure presents with chronic cough and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray shows extensive lung fibrosis, and he is diagnosed with pneumoconiosis. Which particle size is most dangerous for causing pneumoconiosis by reaching the lower respiratory tract?
questions.explanation:
Particle Size

Effects on Respiratory Tract

5-10 μm

It gets trapped in the upper respiratory tract.

3-5 μm

Deposits in the mid-respiratory tract.

0.5-3 μm

It enters the alveoli and causes damage.

Less than 0.5 μm

Moves deeper due to Brownian motion into smaller airways.

questions.text: A 30-year-old construction worker presents with painful muscle spasms after several hours of heavy sweating in the hot sun. He reports extreme thirst and muscle tightness, but his vital signs are normal. Which heat-related illness is primarily caused by loss of sodium and chloride during heavy physical work in high temperatures?
questions.explanation:
Heat Disorder

Mechanism

Features

Treatment

Heat Cramps

(Option C)

Loss of sodium and chlorides due to heavy muscular work.

Painful, spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles.

Rehydration and electrolyte replacement; rest and stretching of affected muscles.

Heat Stroke

(Option A)

Failure of heat-regulating mechanism.

Very high body temperature (> 110°F or 43.3°C), delirium, convulsions, partial or complete loss of consciousness, dry and hot skin

  • Classical heat stroke occurs in vulnerable populations during heatwaves, while Exertional heat stroke occurs in healthy individuals during intense physical activity in hot conditions.

Rapid cooling in an ice water bath until rectal temperature falls below 102°F (38.9°C). Continuous monitoring of rectal temperature. Supportive care for complications.

Heat Exhaustion

(Option B)

Imbalance or inadequate replacement of water and salts lost through perspiration.

Normal or moderately elevated body temperature (< 102°F or 38.9°C)

Dizziness, weakness, fatigue, circulatory distress,

Normalise fluid and electrolyte balance; may require hospitalization in severe cases.

Heat Syncope

(Option C)

Blood pooling in lower limbs due to dilated blood vessels.

Pale skin, sudden collapse, no significant rise in body temperature

Lay down in the shade with your head slightly down; recovery typically takes 5-10 minutes.
